statements.text: A set system is a family of sets visualized using Venn diagrams or Euler diagrams.
Venn diagrams show all possible intersections among small set systems using overlapping closed curves.
Euler diagrams remove empty regions from Venn diagrams, emphasizing actual relationships in a set system.
Linear diagrams represent sets as parallel lines where overlapping segments encode intersections between set systems.
UpSet plots replace overlapping regions of Venn diagrams with matrix layouts for large set systems.
RectEuler diagrams draw each set in a set system as a rectangle, emphasizing containment relationships.
Hypergraphs generalize set systems by treating sets as hyperedges, also visualized with bipartite graphs.
Bipartite graphs represent a set system with element nodes connected to set nodes.
Incidence matrices encode membership of elements in sets, linking set systems to linear algebraic operations.
Contingency tables summarize frequencies for combinations of set memberships, closely related to incidence matrices.
Hierarchical clustering groups similar sets or elements, and dendrograms reveal structure within large set systems.
Multisets extend set systems by allowing repeated elements, which some visualization techniques must handle explicitly.
UpSet plots and contingency tables highlight high-order intersections that overwhelm traditional Venn diagrams.
RectEuler diagrams and Euler diagrams emphasize containment in set systems but handle disconnected regions differently.
Linear diagrams and bipartite graphs can be easier to read than crowded Venn diagrams.
Hypergraphs, incidence matrices and bipartite graphs form an algebraic and combinatorial view of set systems.
Hierarchical clustering can be combined with UpSet plots to order sets and intersections coherently.
Multisets and set systems with weights require extending incidence matrices and contingency tables with counts.
Researchers compare Venn diagrams, UpSet plots and RectEuler diagrams when choosing set visualization techniques.
Modern tools integrate multiple techniques, letting analysts switch between Euler diagrams and UpSet plots interactively.
